GeneralClean Architecture Standards

App Architecture Guide

Comprehensive standards and quick reference for .NET Clean Architecture and Vertical Slice patterns.

For detailed examples and explanations, see the full Coding Standards Guide. This is a quick reference for daily development and code reviews.

Our architecture standards ensure consistency across services. We support two primary patterns based on complexity: Clean Architecture for rich domains and Vertical Slice for feature-focused or CRUD-heavy applications.

The Developer Handbook

If you're new to AII, here's the absolute essentials you need to know about our architectural philosophy:

Layered Isolation

The Domain Layer is the center and must NEVER depend on Infrastructure or WebApi.

Dependency Flow

Dependencies always point inwards. Use Interfaces to decouple logic.

Feature Focus

Vertical Slice allows for faster delivery by grouping logic by feature instead of layer.

Architecture Decisions

Clean Architecture
Complex Domains
Domain → Application → Infrastructure → WebApi

Focuses on business logic isolation and strict layer boundaries.

  • Rich business logic / Long-term projects
  • Multiple applications sharing the same domain
Vertical Slice
CRUD Heavy
Features/Orders/Create/, Features/Orders/GetById/

Focuses on high cohesion by co-locating all code related to a specific feature.

  • Independent features / Rapid development
  • Smaller teams or microservices context

Design Patterns

Pattern Overview

Decouples commands (writes) and queries (reads). Uses MediatR for pipeline behaviors like logging and validation.

csharpCQRS Implementation
public record CreateOrderCommand(string Product) : IRequest<OrderResult>;
public class CreateOrderHandler : IRequestHandler<CreateOrderCommand, OrderResult>

Data Access

1

Option 1: Repository Pattern

Abstraction over EF Core, essential for CA/Testing.

Testing abstraction needed, multiple data sources.

2

Option 2: Generic Repository + UoW

Consistent patterns for bulk entities.

Many similar entities, transaction coordination.

3

Option 3: Direct DbContext

Highest performance, lowest complexity.

Simple operations, Vertical Slice, performance critical.

Quick Standards Checklist

Naming Conventions

  • Classes PascalCase
  • Interfaces IPascalCase
  • Methods PascalCaseAsync
  • Fields (private) _camelCase

Async/Await Rules

✅ DO: Async all the way through

return await _repository.GetByIdAsync(id, ct);

❌ DON'T: Block async calls

var res = GetAsync().Result; // CRITICAL!

Recommended Project Structure

src/
├── Domain/           # Entities, ValueObjects, Domain Interfaces
├── Application/      # UseCases, DTOs, Validators
├── Infrastructure/   # DbContext, Repositories, Services
└── WebApi/           # Controllers, Middleware, Auth

Testing Patterns

Unit Test Structure (AAA)

Arrange, Act, Assert. Everything must be isolatable.

csharpTest Example
[Test]
public async Task Handle_ValidRequest_ReturnsSuccess()
{
    // Arrange
    var cmd = new CreateOrderCommand("Prod");
    // Act
    var result = await _handler.Handle(cmd, CancellationToken.None);
    // Assert
    Assert.That(result.Success, Is.True);
}

Decision Matrix

ScenarioArchitecturePatternData Access
Complex LogicClean ArchCQRSRepository
CRUD ApplicationVertical SliceServicesDirect DbContext
MicroserviceVertical SliceCQRSDirect DbContext
Enterprise AppClean ArchCQRSRepository + UoW

Common Mistakes to Avoid

Mixing Patterns

Don't use OrderService and ISender for the same logic.

Blocking Async

Avoid .Result or .Wait() at all costs.

Entities in API

Never return Domain Entities directly; always use DTOs.

Logic in Controllers

Controllers should only orchestrate, never handle business rules.
